author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Jesse McKinley
title: Aide Says Cuomo Groped Her, as New Details of Account Emerge
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo characterized the new allegations as “gut-wrenching,” but insisted that he has “never done anything like this.”
content: An aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo who had accused the governor of improper behavior said that Mr. Cuomo had groped her in the Executive Mansion, according to new details of her account reported by The Times Union of Albany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Even Stuck at Home, These Clothes Will Take You Places
description: Going through the looking glass with Dior, up in the mountains at Miu Miu and on an odyssey with Louis Vuitton.
content: Almost exactly a year ago, the Louis Vuitton show, held in the courtyard of the Louvre, brought the curtain down on the runway circus as it once was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ludwig Hurtado
title: Storytime Lets Fathers Form Bonds From Behind Bars
description: Across the country, inmates are distance-reading bedtime stories to their kids and finding their own paths to redemption.
content: Greg Williams, 45, doesn’t remember the first book he read to his daughters in 2006, but he remembers picking the shortest book in a stack, hoping he could get to the end without crying on camera. He imagined his girls in their pajamas, tucked into bed, listening. As he turned each page, he imagined that he was there, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Brother Hasn’t Buried Our Mother’s Ashes Yet, and I’m Mad
description: He works full time and is also managing her estate, but is that really an excuse?
content: My mother died in June and was cremated, as provided in her will. For practical reasons, my brother took possession of her ashes. Now it’s March, and he hasn’t done a single thing about burying her ashes beside my father’s, as she requested. When I reminded him, he got defensive and changed the subject.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Jewelry carved from bone, a cookbook from a beloved restaurant — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: I.O.C. Will Buy Coronavirus Vaccines From China for Olympians
description: The agreement with a powerful Olympic partner may help reassure a skeptical Japanese population fearful of thousands of visitors to this summer’s Games.
content: In what amounts to a public relations coup for China and a solution to a problem for the International Olympic Committee, the I.O.C. president, Thomas Bach, announced on Thursday that China had agreed to provide coronavirus vaccines for any participant requiring one ahead of this summer’s Tokyo Olympics and next year’s Beijing Winter Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serena Solomon
title: The America’s Cup Is Now an Action Movie
description: High-tech racing boats and low-flying helicopters bring close-quarters drama to sailing’s biggest races. But staying out of the way is harder than it looks.
content: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — The main attraction for spectators and television viewers at the America’s Cup will always be the AC75s, the sleek racing yachts that can fly above the water on hydrofoils at speeds as high as 60 miles an hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Peter Semler, Career Diplomat During Cold War, Dies at 89
description: A well-traveled Foreign Service officer, he had posts across Europe from the 1950s through the collapse of the Soviet Union. He died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Why $4-a-Gallon Gas May Be Coming Your Way This Summer
description: The oil industry, known for boom-bust cycles, is resisting the temptation to pump more oil — for now.
content: HOUSTON — Even as oil and gasoline prices rise, industry executives are resisting their usual impulse to pump more oil out of the ground, which could keep energy prices moving up as the economy recovers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: N.H.L. Returns to ESPN in a 7-Year Deal With an Emphasis on Streaming
description: The agreement assures hockey a higher profile on SportsCenter and gives ESPN the perfect sport for its streaming ambitions
content: After an absence of 16 years, the National Hockey League is returning to ESPN.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary D. Carter
title: The Coronavirus Killed the Gospel of Small Government
description: The crisis showed, once and for all, that things fall apart when the government steps aside.
content: Suddenly, it was everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Cohen
title: The Coronavirus Made the Radical Possible
description: The past year has seen progressive pipe dreams become reality. But can we hold on to what we’ve learned?
content: Last spring, as a poorly understood virus swept the planet­, something remarkable happened: Across the country, all levels of government put in place policies that just a few months earlier would have been seen by most people — not to mention most politicians — as radical and politically naïve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Still Life in Lodz’ Review: A Painting Becomes a Window
description: This documentary examines how objects can create through lines across history.
content: The loosely observed conceit of “Still Life in Lodz” is that certain objects bear passive witness to history. In this documentary, directed by Slawomir Grunberg, Lilka Elbaum, a historical researcher born in Lodz, Poland, starts with a painting from the apartment in Lodz where she grew up. The painting had hung on a wall there since 1893, she says. It was the first thing she saw in the morning, and its absence left a “gaping wound” on the wall when her family left Poland in 1968, emigrating to North America to escape anti-Semitism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Georgetown Law Fires Professor for ‘Abhorrent’ Remarks About Black Students
description: The law school said Sandra A. Sellers, an adjunct professor, had been terminated, and David C. Batson, another adjunct, had been placed on administrative leave.
content: Georgetown University Law Center said on Thursday that it had fired an adjunct professor who made “abhorrent” remarks about Black students on a video call and had placed another adjunct who was on the call with her on administrative leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: A Rundown School for Palestinian Children Awaits U.S. Aid
description: Residents worry that the Biden administration won’t restore critical funding for the renovation of the West Bank school.
content: JABA, West Bank — When Joe Biden was elected president, residents of the tiny hilltop village of Jaba in the occupied West Bank cheered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Lou Ottens, Father of Countless Mixtapes, Is Dead at 94
description: He led the team at Philips that changed the audio world in 1963 by introducing a small, portable way to play and record: the cassette.
content: In these digital days, it may be hard to appreciate how radically Lou Ottens changed the audio world when, in 1963, he and his team at Philips, the Dutch electronics company, introduced the cassette tape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: The embattled head of the federal student aid office has resigned.
description: Mark Brown was appointed by Betsy DeVos, the former education secretary, to be the head of the Office of Federal Student Aid.
content: From almost the day he was tapped to head the Office of Federal Student Aid under the Trump administration, Mark A. Brown was a target of consumer and labor groups aligned with the progressive wing of the Democratic Party. This week, they cheered his resignation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Pinkowski
title: She Was Buried With a Silver Crown. Was She the One Who Held Power?
description: A tomb unearthed in Spain prompts archaeologists to reconsider assumptions about women’s power in Bronze Age European societies.
content: About 3,700 years ago, a man and a woman were buried together in the southeast of the Iberian Peninsula. Their tomb was an ovoid jar beneath the floor of a grand hall in an expansive hilltop complex known as La Almoloya, in what is now Murcia, Spain. It’s one of many archaeological sites associated with the El Argar culture of the Early Bronze Age that controlled an area about the size of Belgium from 2200 B.C. to 1500 B.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Lisa Prevost
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., and Darien, Conn.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josie Thaddeus-Johns
title: What Are NFTs, Anyway? One Just Sold for $69 Million.
description: “Nonfungible tokens” and blockchain technology are taking the mainstream art world by storm, fetching huge prices. We explain, or try to.
content: The artist Mike Winkelmann, also known as Beeple, has just sold an NFT at a record-breaking $69.3 million, the third-highest price achieved by a living artist. The sale, at Christie’s, for the purely digital work was the strongest indication yet that NFTs, or “nonfungible tokens,” have taken the art market by storm, making the leap from specialist websites to premier auction houses. Beeple, a newcomer to the fine-art world who first heard about NFTs five months ago, is the most high-profile artist to profit off the huge boom in sales of these much hyped but poorly understood commodities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Wilhelmina Cole Holladay, Whose Art Museum Promoted Women, Dies at 98
description: She used her networking skills and social connections to establish the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington, the first of its kind.
content: Wilhelmina Cole Holladay, who used her social connections, organizational acumen and personal collection of hundreds of works by female painters to establish the country’s first museum dedicated to women in the arts, died on Saturday at her home in Washington. She was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: In UConn, the ‘New Big East’ Has Welcomed an Old Power
description: The Huskies were expected to make the N.C.A.A. tournament entering the Big East men’s basketball tournament, their first in nine years.
content: When R.J. Cole transferred from Howard to UConn after his sophomore season, he sought to test himself against better competition, move closer to his family and compete on a bigger stage in the Big East Conference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Norm Sherry, 89, Dies; Gave Koufax a Tip, and the Rest Is History
description: His suggestion to his Dodger teammate Sandy Koufax helped turn him from a pitcher with control problems into a Hall of Famer.
content: Norm Sherry, whose suggestion to the future Hall of Fame pitcher Sandy Koufax when they were teammates helped Koufax reach his potential and become one of the most dominant pitchers of his era, died on Monday in San Juan Capistrano, Calif. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerry Garrett
title: A Legendary Designer Strikes Out on His Own to Redesign Legends
description: For two decades, Ian Callum led the look at Jaguar Land Rover. Now he’s reimagining some vintage cars, including the Jag Mark 2 and a classic Corvette.
content: Ian Callum, the noted automotive designer, has started a new company, simply named Callum Design. It could just as easily be called Unfinished Business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: For a second St. Patrick’s Day without parades, some places find other ways to celebrate.
description: Some events are relocating to the water, some are being postponed, and others are now taking place in cars.
content: The pandemic in the United States, now more than a year old, is starting to hit some calendar milestones for a second time, including St. Patrick’s Day parades across the country. The sudden cancellation of the parades last year was one of the first big signs of how disruptive the pandemic would be to normal life in the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Hollywood Loses $10 Billion a Year Due to Lack of Diversity, Study Finds
description: A McKinsey report that combined previous research and new interviews argues that concrete steps like company bonuses tied to improved representation can lead to change.
content: By ignoring the systemic racial inequities that plague the film and television business, Hollywood is leaving $10 billion annually on the table. That is one of the main findings in a new report from the management consulting firm McKinsey & Company, which for the first time turned its attention to the lack of Black representation in Hollywood. And, unlike many other studies that do excellent jobs of pointing out problems without giving concrete solutions, this one includes a series of steps that could help change the makeup of the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Uncertain Recovery of Manhattan’s Chinatown
description: Jing Fong’s banquet hall was geographically and symbolically at the heart of neighborhood, and its closing was a major loss.

title: Jeffrey Epstein’s Manhattan mansion fetches $51 million after a judge denies a request to freeze the sale.
description: A deed for the sale has yet to be recorded, but one of the estate’s lawyers said that funds from the sale were being transferred to a compensation program for Mr. Epstein’s victims.
content: Jeffrey Epstein’s Manhattan mansion has been sold to an unidentified buyer for about $51 million, which will go to a fund providing restitution for the disgraced financier’s sexual abuse victims.

title: The Status of the Pandemic, in Three Charts
description: Virus trends in the U.S. are improving, largely because of the rising level of immunity.
content: Public discussion of “herd immunity” often treats it like an on-off switch: When the U.S. reaches herd immunity, the crisis will be over; until then, the country has little immunity from Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maira Khwaja, Trina Reynolds-Tyler, Dominique James and Hannah Nyhart
title: Our Year of Mutual Aid
description: In Chicago, groups of volunteers gave us a glimpse of a society where neighbors rely on one another.
content: CHICAGO — “Free foooood!” It was a hot morning in late July, and many were gathered outside an elementary school to distribute groceries to the community. The DJ played Beyoncé’s “Before I Let Go” as volunteers and people in line danced, six feet apart. Children of the neighborhood ran by to get snack packs and coloring books, and stayed to help elders carry their groceries. Regulars sat out in their chairs, just as they do every Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Senate’s F-Bomb
description: Meet the folks who can slow anything down.
content: Wow, stuff is … happening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Gaia Pianigiani
title: Volleyball Player Lost Her Job Over Pregnancy. Now She’s Fighting Back.
description: It is common for paid women athletes in Italy to be forced to leave after they get pregnant. Now one of them has ignited a debate that was a long time coming.
content: ROME — When the Italian volleyball player Lara Lugli got pregnant, she knew she would lose her job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Johnson & Johnson’s one-shot vaccine is approved by the European Union.
description: The decision opens the way for the delivery of 200 million doses ti help speed vaccination efforts.
content: The European Union authorized use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine on Thursday, amid mounting frustration with a sluggish inoculation campaign that has been hobbled by supply shocks and logistics failures, and with global wars over scarce doses ratcheting up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Druckerman
title: How Do Maya Parents Handle Temper Tantrums?
description: In “Hunt, Gather, Parent,” Michaeleen Doucleff visits with Indigenous people to pick up parenting tactics that Western cultures may be sorely lacking.
content: HUNT, GATHER, PARENTWhat Ancient Cultures Can Teach Us About the Lost Art of Raising Happy, Helpful Little HumansBy Michaeleen Doucleff
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: A Small Town and a Spray of Bullets in Myanmar
description: Police officers shot into a cluster of unarmed civilians in a tiny town on Thursday, killing at least eight people and injuring more than 20.
content: Until Thursday, Myaing, a small town in central Myanmar, was best known for its production of thanaka, a bark that is ground for use as a cooling cosmetic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Bliss and Anger in Balance: The Art of Lorraine O’Grady
description: A survey at the Brooklyn Museum radiates high outrage even as it finds beauty and strength in a range of identities.
content: Back in the 1960s, some of us were taking drugs, scrambling genders, and sampling global religions to shake ourselves loose from what we saw as Western-style binary thinking, a view of the world based on strictly held good-bad, right-wrong opposites: white versus Black, straight versus gay, us versus them. Five decades later, such thinking still rules in a red-blue nation, which makes the retrospective of Lorraine O’Grady’s career at the Brooklyn Museum a major corrective event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: The Pentagon condemns Tucker Carlson’s sexist remarks about women in the military.
description: The Fox News host’s comments came days after two women were nominated to lead two of the military’s combatant commands.
content: The Pentagon’s press secretary, John F. Kirby, on Thursday publicly rebuked Tucker Carlson for sexist comments made by the Fox News host, in which Mr. Carlson ridiculed recent changes the military had made to be more accommodating to women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Scramble
description: Leslie Rogers feeds our love of puzzles.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — If the grid for this puzzle made you do a double-take when you first looked at it, you’re not alone. This grid uses mirror symmetry, as opposed to the typical rotational symmetry, so it might look strange if you’re unfamiliar with it. Combined with a nice lateral-thinking theme, the puzzle is both elegantly constructed, and an engaging solving experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Garrett Bradley Reminds Us That Black Joy Always Existed
description: Her elaborate video installation, which restages quiet and remarkable moments in early 20th-century Black life, is at the Museum of Modern Art.
content: Garrett Bradley’s quicksilver, imperious video installation “America,” at the Museum of Modern Art is an indictment wrapped in a celebration. Completed in 2019, it reimagines some of the signal events of Black life and culture in the United States during the early decades of the 20th century — reclaiming lost or overlooked pieces of history in a display of inexhaustible narrative and spatial complexity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Masuike and Russell Goldman
title: A Village Erased
description: The earthquake and tsunami of March 11, 2011, wiped away the ancient Japanese village of Kesen. In the past decade, a small group of survivors has valiantly tried to rebuild the community, but a grim reality has set in: This emptiness will last forever.
content: KESEN, Japan — For centuries, this village rode the currents of time: war and plague, the sowing and reaping of rice, the planting and felling of trees.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Freedom of Natural Curls: Egypt’s Quiet Rebellion
description: For decades, many Egyptians have been straightening their hair to fit a conservative, Western-influenced beauty standard. Many younger Egyptians are rejecting all that.
content: CAIRO — There’s a TV commercial from the 1980s that some Egyptians remember well: Two women stand at a mirror, one with thick, dark curls, the other draped in sleek, glossy tresses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Relief Bill Gives Airline and Airport Workers a Reprieve, for Now
description: Aviation workers will be protected from furloughs through September under the bill President Biden signed Thursday, but a full travel recovery could take years.
content: The pandemic relief bill that President Biden signed Thursday afternoon will protect tens of thousands of aviation jobs, providing a lifeline to an industry that is likely to struggle for some time even as vaccinations accelerate.

title: When Your West Wing Job Is Really, Really Far From the Oval Office
description: Because of the pandemic, some Biden administration officials continue to work from homes a long way from Washington. They see advantages in being outside the bubble.
content: WASHINGTON — Emmy Ruiz, 37, was shoveling snow into a bucket in her backyard one frigid morning last month with her toddler while dialing into a conference call for work.

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Tony La Russa Came Back Because the ‘Opportunity Is Real’
description: He won three World Series titles on his way to the Hall of Fame, and the new (old) manager of the Chicago White Sox believes this roster compares to his best.
content: Hallowed names caromed off the walls of the coaches' room one recent morning at the Chicago White Sox’ camp in Glendale, Ariz. The former slugger Jim Thome was in town, and as coaches prepared the day’s schedule, Thome rattled off a list of the greatest players ever managed by a fellow Hall of Famer, Tony La Russa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Ed Shanahan
title: He Was Caught Jaywalking. He Was Almost Deported for It.
description: Javier Castillo Maradiaga was freed this week after 15 months in federal detention. New York had turned him over to ICE in error.
content: Javier Castillo Maradiaga was on his way to a family birthday party in the Bronx in December 2019 when the police arrested him for jaywalking.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Joe Biden Is a Transformational President
description: We’re seeing a policy realignment without a partisan realignment.
content: This has been one of the most quietly consequential weeks in recent American politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: A vaccine-exporting powerhouse.
content: Despite being accused of “vaccine nationalism” and protectionism, the European Union has exported 34 million doses of coronavirus vaccines in recent weeks to dozens of countries, even as it trails behind the United States, Britain and Israel in its own vaccine drive, according to internal documents seen by The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Two whistle-blowers claim a Justice Department official improperly promoted an employee in the final days of Trump’s term.
description: The whistle-blowers allege that Jeffrey Bossert Clark politicized the hiring process before leaving the Justice Department.
content: Two whistle-blowers on Wednesday accused Jeffrey Bossert Clark, a former Justice Department official, of politicizing the hiring process in the waning days of President Donald J. Trump’s tenure by improperly elevating an employee who was seen as loyal to the former president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Aleksander Doba, Who Kayaked Across the Atlantic, Dies at 74
description: He hungered to paddle across an ocean so vast it seemed infinite. He did it three times, setting records and becoming a national hero in Poland.
content: Aleksander Doba, a Polish adventurer who kayaked alone across the Atlantic at the age of 70 while subsisting on his wife’s fortifying plum jam — after having twice paddled solo across the Atlantic when he was in his 60s — died on Feb. 22 on the summit of Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania, Africa. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Where Fitness Is the Job, Army Struggles to Be a Fair Boss With Female Troops
description: As the Army revises its physical test and otherwise rethinks fitness, it faces difficult questions: Do current requirements penalize women? Do they overshadow expertise and intellectual preparation?
content: WASHINGTON — For 99 percent of Americans, this question will never come up in a job interview: Can you hang from a bar and tuck your legs to your chest?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Meyers Leonard Fined $50,000 and Suspended for Using an Anti-Semitic Slur
description: Leonard, a reserve center for the N.B.A.’s Miami Heat, said the slur while playing a video game on a public livestream.

author: By Steve Lohr
title: Companies That Rode Pandemic Boom Get a Reality Check
description: Investors, who flocked to companies like Zoom as the virus spread, have started to look elsewhere.
content: While the pandemic battered the economy, tech companies and consumer companies powered by digital technology stood out as islands of growth.

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Prince William Calls Royals ‘Not a Racist Family’ After Meghan and Harry Interview
description: His comment, after remarks made by the couple in their interview with Oprah Winfrey that aired this week, was the first from a member of the royal family in a public appearance.
content: LONDON — Prince William on Thursday denied that Britain’s royal family was racist, in his first public comments after his brother, Prince Harry, and Harry’s wife, Meghan, alleged in a bombshell interview that a family member had raised concerns about their child’s skin tone and shared revelations about a rift in the usually tight-lipped institution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Fein Revell
title: Nobody Wants Cancer. But a ‘Big C’ Label Has Surprising Upsides.
description: Classifying a rare blood disorder as a cancer opened new doors for disease investigation, treatment and hope for a cure.
content: I have a rare blood disorder. When it was diagnosed 25 years ago, it was called an “orphan disease,” meaning the small number of people affected didn’t justify research investments by major pharmaceutical companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Grammys Ready Pandemic Show, as the Weeknd Boycotts Future Awards​
description: The event on Sunday will address the challenges of a music industry hit hard by the pandemic. The Weeknd, who was snubbed, says he will boycott the awards going forward, in a sign of continuing friction with artists.
content: When music fans tune in to the 63rd annual Grammy Awards on Sunday night, with Trevor Noah as host and performances by nearly two dozen stars including Taylor Swift, Cardi B, Dua Lipa and BTS, they will see the music world coming together in celebration and friendly competition after a grueling year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Essential Oils May Be Wreaking Havoc on Your Skin
description: When it comes to clean beauty, “natural” isn’t always best. Here’s what’s safe and beneficial, and what’s best to avoid.
content: When Kristen Fanarakis emerged from a facial at an all-natural salon in Atlanta, her face did not have the fresh, glossy glow she had hoped for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Spike Lee Predicts the Future
description: The director of “Da 5 Bloods” talks about why his old movies still resonate, whether an awards snub even matters and how it’s not his job to end racism.
content: Spike Lee has a knack for seeing what’s ahead. After Eric Garner’s death in 2014 and George Floyd’s death last year, Mr. Lee’s 1989 film “Do the Right Thing,” which culminates in a violent confrontation between a Black character and a white police officer, was seen as downright prophetic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: A growing number of U.S. states are expanding vaccine eligibility.
description: Alaska, Georgia, Minnesota, New York, Ohio and Texas are among those offering shots to more people amid an energized national inoculation campaign.
content: As vaccine production and deliveries and inoculations ramp up, a growing number of U.S. states are allowing ever more people to get vaccinated, providing optimism for those who have been waiting for their moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lovia Gyarkye
title: ‘The Inheritance’ Review: Poetry, Visualized
description: In this feature, a Black collective becomes a site of robust intellectual exchange, inspired artistry, joy and humor.
content: “The Inheritance,” Ephraim Asili’s debut feature film, beautifully abandons genre to consider questions about community, art and Black liberation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Thomas Kaplan
title: A G.O.P. senator tweets approvingly about part of the stimulus bill, without mentioning one detail: his ‘no’ vote.
description: “I’m not going to vote for $1.9 trillion just because it has a couple of good provisions,” Senator Roger Wicker later told reporters.
content: Before the House gave final approval to a $1.9 trillion stimulus package on Wednesday without any Republican support, Speaker Nancy Pelosi admonished Republicans for their opposition to the measure, declaring, “It’s typical that they vote no and take the dough.”

author: By Brett Berk
title: A Postwar Mercedes, Still Overshadowed by Its Racing Cousins
description: The Adenauer Benz helped lift the automaker after its work for the Nazis. Today, pristine models go for a small fraction of Gullwings from the same era.
content: After World War II, Mercedes-Benz wanted to re-establish its position in the automotive hierarchy, to create a car that, in the words of the board chairman at the time, Wilhelm Haspel, “gold-plates the name Mercedes-Benz again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Billy Witz
title: Duke’s Exit From A.C.C. Tournament Is a Reminder of the Pandemic’s Threat
description: The trouble for the Blue Devils will likely spark new skepticism of the N.C.A.A.’s plan to hold the national men’s basketball tournament next week in Indiana.
content: The men’s basketball team at Duke University was one of the weaker teams in its conference. A freshman had decided in February to declare for the N.B.A. draft and not play the rest of the season. With a 13-11 record, the Blue Devils’ prospects for making the N.C.A.A. tournament were among their dimmest in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Derek Chauvin will now face a third-degree murder charge.
description: The judge overseeing the trial of the former police officer charged with killing George Floyd has allowed prosecutors to add an additional charge.
content: The judge overseeing the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with killing George Floyd, has allowed prosecutors to add an additional charge of third-degree murder against Mr. Chauvin, who is already facing a more serious count of second-degree murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Honeydew’ Review: Homegrown Horror
description: A camping trip gone wrong lands a tetchy couple at a remote farm in this horror tale.
content: Harold Bloom’s 1973 book “The Anxiety of Influence” looked at the crisis of poets trying to create new work while contending with the aesthetic sway held over them by their forebears. Someday, a film critic, one with plenty of viewing experience, might want to write about the irritation of influence, particularly as it applies to genre film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: How a Museum Show Honoring Breonna Taylor Is Trying to ‘Get It Right’
description: An upcoming exhibition brings Black contemporary artists to Louisville’s Speed Art Museum to honor Taylor and her legacy. For the curator Allison Glenn, it’s been an intense journey.
content: “Promise, Witness, Remembrance” — an exhibition opening April 7 at the Speed Art Museum in Louisville, Ky., in honor of Breonna Taylor, the 26-year-old medical worker killed by police there nearly a year ago — came together fast, yet in a manner “tempered by conversations,” said its curator Allison Glenn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: He Went to 105 Shows in One Season. Now He Watches TV.
description: What has this year been like for the most voracious of culture vultures? A super fan in Chicago lets us into his life without the arts.
content: Edward T. Minieka was 5 years old when his parents started taking him to see shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: BAM’s 2021 Season Will Be Outdoors and Online
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music’s programming will feature intimate concerts, dancers on ice skates and a play presented in the Botanic Garden.
content: The Brooklyn Academy of Music’s 2021 season will feature a mix of outdoor performances and public art — including concerts played to individual audience members — as well as lectures and music delivered virtually, the organization announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Celebrates the Passing of the Stimulus Bill
description: “There you go, baby. You’re rich! Buy yourself something nice, like rent or medicine,” Colbert said on Wednesday’s “Late Show.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
content: In 1995, the British choreographer Matthew Bourne audaciously reimagined the revered 19th-century ballet “Swan Lake,” transforming the ethereal female bevy into a flock of feral men. The production, a blend of contemporary dance and Broadway spectacle, became an international sensation and, a quarter century later, was one of the last seen on New York City Center’s stage before Covid-19 arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Schonbrun
title: The Lawyer Who Became a (Pitching) Ninja
description: Rob Friedman has a huge social media following, top pitchers who swear by him and deals with ESPN and M.L.B. But he insists this is just a hobby.
content: DECATUR, Ga. — It is sometimes difficult to tell where Rob Friedman’s professional work ends and his hobby begins. On a visit to his home outside Atlanta, Friedman occasionally will stop midsentence, glance at his phone, and then take off sprinting in the direction of his home office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta, Catrin Einhorn and Manuela Andreoni
title: There’s a Global Plan to Conserve Nature. Indigenous People Could Lead the Way.
description: Dozens of countries are backing an effort that would protect 30 percent of Earth’s land and water. Native people, often among the most effective stewards of nature, have been disregarded, or worse, in the past.
content: With a million species at risk of extinction, dozens of countries are pushing to protect at least 30 percent of the planet’s land and water by 2030. Their goal is to hammer out a global agreement at negotiations to be held in China later this year, designed to keep intact natural areas like old growth forests and wetlands that nurture biodiversity, store carbon and filter water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: The Year Grandparents Lost
description: The enforced separations of the pandemic have brought a particular kind of mourning to many grandparents.
content: Kathy Koehler had made elaborate plans to meet her first grandchild. Her daughter, who was expecting a baby last March, lived in London, and Ms. Koehler intended to fly there from her home in Ann Arbor, Mich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Tanzanian President’s Absence Fuels Speculation About His Health
description: For months John Magufuli railed against masks, social distancing and vaccines. Now rumors are circulating that he’s critically ill with Covid-19.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — As unrecorded numbers of Tanzanians succumbed to the coronavirus, the country’s president consistently downplayed the pandemic, dismissing protective measures, scoffing at vaccines and saying God had helped to eliminate the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Looking to rapidly boost the U.S. economy, Biden highlights ‘massive effort to reopen our schools safely.’
description: The stimulus bill President Biden signed on Thursday includes several provisions meant to quickly put money in the hands of low- and middle-income segments of the population.
content: Just hours after he signed a $1.9 trillion pandemic relief bill into law, President Biden said the package would help to reopen schools and defeat the virus more quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Suleika Jaouad Does Not Want to Be Your Mountaintop Sage
description: But “Between Two Kingdoms,” her memoir of cancer and its aftermath, is striking a chord with readers who are enduring ordeals of their own.
content: ROAD WARRIOR In the month since the publication of her memoir, “Between Two Kingdoms,” which just spent three weeks on the hardcover nonfiction list, Suleika Jaoaud has heard from a number of individuals she didn’t expect to be in touch with — including her fourth grade teacher; a California oncologist who was a fellow at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City when Jaoaud was diagnosed with leukemia at the age of 22; and a lawyer offering counsel to a Texas prisoner Jaouad writes about in the book.
source.name: The New York Times

title: California Man Admits He Threatened Baseball Players
description: Benjamin Tucker Patz, who has a history of sports gambling, faces a maximum of five years in prison and up to $250,000 in fines, according to federal prosecutors in Florida.
content: A California man with a history of sports gambling has pleaded guilty to sending threatening messages on Instagram to several athletes, including one in which he told a baseball player, “I will kill your entire family,” federal officials announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ending the End of Welfare as We Knew It
description: The Democrats’ new child benefit is a very big deal.
content: The era of “the era of big government is over” is over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: This Black Family Ran a Thriving Beach Resort 100 Years Ago. They Want Their Land Back.
description: Willa and Charles Bruce were among the first Black people to settle in Manhattan Beach, Calif., but the city shut down their resort in 1924. Now, the county is considering returning the land.
content: In 1912, Willa and Charles Bruce bought a plot of land on the Southern California coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Detroit Museum Tries to Change After Review Cites a Culture of Fear
description: Outside investigators hired by the Detroit Institute of Arts said that current and ex-employees told them they had feared retaliation if they disagreed with leadership.
content: The Detroit Institute of Arts is taking steps to improve its workplace culture following a critical review by outside investigators who said they had fielded employee complaints of retaliation by the director whose autocratic leadership style, they said, had fostered an environment that led a disproportionate number of women on staff to leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: The Fight Is On to Define the Pandemic Aid Bill
description: Democrats have embraced the scope and cost of the stimulus measure, daring Republicans to campaign against the myriad benefits it delivers for their constituents.
content: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans and Democrats finally agree on something: The pandemic rescue bill President Biden signed into law on Thursday is the largest expansion of government support programs in more than 50 years. Where they differ is on whether that is good or bad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: The E.U. extends vaccine export controls until the end of June.
description: The European Union will extend a mechanism that permits it to block exports of coronavirus vaccines abroad by three months, to the end of June, the bloc said on Thursday, as global trade wars over scarce doses ratchet up.
content: The European Union will extend a mechanism that permits it to block exports of coronavirus vaccines abroad by three months, to the end of June, the bloc said on Thursday, as global trade wars over scarce doses ratchet up.

author: By Jennifer Murphy
title: I Was an E.M.T. in New York Last Spring
description: The losses emergency responders witnessed are beyond what human minds can grasp.
content: One of my most vivid memories from last April is the sound. I was working as an emergency medical technician in New York City. Day and night for weeks, sirens drowned out every other sound within earshot. A doctor told me, “The sound of sirens will be how we all remember this for the rest of our lives.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Carl Hulse and Jonathan Martin
title: With Relief Plan, Biden Takes on a New Role: Crusader for the Poor
description: President Biden’s new role as a crusader for Americans in poverty is an evolution for a politician who has focused on the working class and his Senate work on the judiciary and foreign relations.
content: WASHINGTON — Days before his inauguration, President-elect Biden was eying a $1.3 trillion rescue plan aimed squarely at the middle class he has always championed, but pared down to attract some Republican support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: Planting, ‘Plogging’ and Sunsets: How to Enjoy That Extra Hour of Daylight
description: “Spring ahead” will come as an even bigger relief than usual after a year of lockdown.
content: With the first anniversary of lockdown fast approaching, I thought I’d been through every possible pandemic milestone. As the months rolled by, I’d checked them off like squares on a Bingo card: First pandemic birthday, first pandemic holiday, first pandemic panic attack in an empty toilet paper aisle at Target.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Quo Vadis, Aida?’ Review: Life and Death in Srebrenica
description: Bosnia and Herzegovina’s Oscar entry is the harrowing and rigorous story of a U.N. translator’s fight to save her family from slaughter.
content: In July 1995, the Bosnian Serb army, under the command of Gen. Ratko Mladic, overran the town of Srebrenica, which had been declared a safe haven by the United Nations. Muslim civilians sought refuge at a nearby U.N. base, but were handed over to Mladic’s soldiers, who separated them by gender and loaded them into buses and trucks. Around 8,000 men and boys were murdered, their bodies buried in mass graves, in one of the worst atrocities of the wars that convulsed the former Yugoslavia for much of the decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Israel’s reopening, and  vaccine doses in limbo.
content: Nearly 60 percent of Israel’s population has received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine. The number of severe cases has dropped. Over the weekend, the country lifted many of the virus restrictions that had been in place for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: European Central Bank to Step Up Stimulus to Keep Borrowing Costs Low
description: The action is a sign that the bank is worried less about inflation than about the economic distress caused by the pandemic.
content: The European Central Bank moved Thursday to counteract market forces that are driving up borrowing costs worldwide, saying it would speed up its purchases of government and corporate bonds to make sure that credit in the eurozone remained cheap.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, March 11, 2021.
content: “We know there is an end in sight. We know the masks work. We know the vaccine distribution is steadily increasing. So why cause hospitalizations and deaths unnecessarily?”

content: Good morning.

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: ‘There Is, in Britain, a Very Big Silence Around Race’
description: For Black and mixed-race Britons, Meghan’s description of her family troubles recalled familiar and often painful experiences that rarely get talked about.
content: LONDON — She was married to the spirited strains of a gospel choir, her veil embroidered with the flowers of Britain’s former colonies, a rare image among rows of white princes and princesses of the post-racial, immigrant society that some imagined Britain to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, John Eligon and Will Wright
title: L.A.P.D. Severely Mishandled George Floyd Protests, Report Finds
description: An independent report commissioned by the Los Angeles City Council faulted the department for its lack of planning and chaotic response.
content: The Los Angeles Police Department severely mishandled protests last summer in the wake of George Floyd’s death, illegally detaining protesters, issuing conflicting orders to its rank-and-file officers and striking people who had committed no crimes with rubber bullets, bean bags and batons, according to a scathing report released on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘Kid 90’ Review: Celluloid Dreams
description: Soleil Moon Frye’s look back at her life as a child star in the 1990s walks the thin line between diary and documentary.
content: At the heart of Soleil Moon Frye’s new film, “Kid 90” (streaming on Hulu), is a startling drive for self-documentation. Beginning in her early teens, Moon Frye, who starred on the popular children’s show “Punky Brewster,” began recording her life with a video camera. She seems to have taken her camcorder everywhere: film sets, road trips, parties with fellow child stars, even her breast reduction surgery at age 15. When she didn’t film something, she recorded her reflections on audiotape or in her journal with precocious introspectiveness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Joe Manchin and Stacey Abrams Can Meet on Common Ground
description: True democracy is within our grasp.
content: There were two columns I wanted to write this week. One was about Senator Joe Manchin’s comments cracking the door open on filibuster reform. The filibuster “should be painful and we’ve made it more comfortable over the years,” he said on “Fox News Sunday.” “Maybe it has to be more painful.” With those words — and, to be fair, a few more Delphic utterances, which I’ll get to shortly — Manchin reignited the possibility of filibuster reform and perhaps the restoration of the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní, J. David Goodman and Jesse McKinley
title: Cuomo Faces New Threat: Impeachment Inquiry Led by Democrats
description: The move by the State Assembly sets the stage for what could be the state’s first impeachment effort in more than a century.
content: New York State lawmakers on Thursday opened an impeachment inquiry into Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, the surest sign yet that the governor was seeing his party turn against him amid growing scrutiny of a recent series of sexual harassment accusations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: A Drone Went Bowling. Hollywood Noticed.
description: A drone video shot in a Minneapolis bowling alley was hailed as an instant classic. One Hollywood veteran said it “adds to the language and vocabulary of cinema.”
content: A drone flies into a bar, swoops through an adjacent bowling alley and crashes into the pins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Which Amenities Are Most Popular?
description: New York City apartment hunters have been asking for these home features in their online searches.
content: Finding the right apartment is always a challenge, and compromise has been the name of the game in expensive and desirable New York City. But according to StreetEasy, apartment hunters have became pickier during the pandemic. One third of searches in 2020 made use of search filters for specific amenities, up from 22 percent in 2019. In mid-November, after receiving requests from users for more searchable amenities, the online listings site added 10 new boxes to check in its search filter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Yoonsoo Kim
title: ‘Long Live Rock … Celebrate the Chaos’ Review: An Ode to Metal
description: With this documentary, a longtime music supervisor, Jonathan McHugh, shines a spotlight on die-hard American rock fans.
content: Aside from the sheer nostalgia of seeing large concert crowds thrashing with abandon (and without masks), the rock ‘n’ roll documentary “Long Live Rock … Celebrate the Chaos,” directed by a longtime music supervisor, Jonathan McHugh, lands on a minor note. Largely consisting of talking heads — from fans and noteworthy talent (Rob Zombie, Jonathan Davis, Ice-T) — the film aims to celebrate the uniqueness of the rock and metal communities, but ends up becoming a repetitive sound clip. Subjects claim that this fandom is different from others, but fail to articulate how. Instead, the sorest thumb that sticks out is the concentration of white fans in the scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: How Some States Are Moving to Restrict Transgender Women in Sports
description: Mississippi is the second state to bar transgender women from women’s sports. More are expected to follow.
content: Gov. Tate Reeves of Mississippi signed a bill on Thursday to bar transgender women and girls from competing in women’s sports, a move Idaho made last year and one that has been recently considered by lawmakers in two dozen other states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Man Sues Hertz Over Lost Receipt That Was His Murder Alibi
description: He spent four years imprisoned on a murder conviction before the car rental company finally located a receipt showing he was nowhere near the scene of the 2011 killing in Michigan.
content: A Michigan man has sued Hertz, the car rental company, saying it failed to produce a receipt that would have proved his innocence before he was convicted of a 2011 murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: JPG File Sells for $69 Million, as ‘NFT Mania’ Gathers Pace
description: “Everydays — The First 5000 Days,” by the artist known as Beeple, set a record for a digital artwork in a sale at Christie’s.
content: After a flurry of more than 180 bids in the final hour, a JPG file made by Mike Winkelmann, the digital artist known as Beeple, was sold on Thursday by Christie’s in an online auction for $69.3 million with fees. The price was a new high for an artwork that exists only digitally, beating auction records for physical paintings by museum-valorized greats like J.M.W. Turner, Georges Seurat and Francisco Goya. Bidding at the two-week Beeple sale, consisting of just one lot, began at $100.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Congress Closes Loophole That Made Veterans a Target of For-Profit Schools
description: The new economic stimulus package makes a tiny change that military veterans pushed for in hopes of stemming aggressive recruiting tactics.

title: Our Lonely Chief Justice
description: A recent solitary dissent by John Roberts points to his isolation from the court’s other conservatives.
content: Anyone who still needs proof of how the Supreme Court is changing need look no further than the single decision the justices handed down this week. The court held that a dispute that had become moot in the usual sense of that word — the problem was resolved before the case even went to trial — could be litigated nonetheless, because there was still something at stake: the one dollar the plaintiffs were seeking as damages for an asserted violation of their First Amendment right to free speech.

content: SEOUL, South Korea — The small white delivery trucks zip down streets all over South Korea. The uniformed workers send photos of safely delivered packages to impatient customers. Workers can move so fast, their employer promises, that it calls the service “rocket delivery.”

title: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Sometimes a book sells itself: Oh, Kazuo Ishiguro’s new novel is a mournful allegory about artificial intelligence and the challenges of human connection? Sign me up, please! (But even if you’re on the same page, do make time to read Radhika Jones’s lovely review of the book; you’ll be glad you did.) Other times a good review makes all the difference. That was the case this week with Mary Roach’s wonderful take on “This Is the Voice,” by John Colapinto, an in-depth nonfiction book about the larynx. Trust me, you’ll want to read it after you read the review.

content: BEIJING — China approved on Thursday a drastic overhaul of election rules for Hong Kong that would most likely bar many pro-democracy politicians from competing in elections, cementing Beijing’s grip over the territory.

author: By Hillary Chute
title: A Child’s-Eye View, Both Haunted and Quotidian
description: In her Graphic Content column, Hillary Chute looks at two graphic works for young people, including the Nobel laureate Olga Tokarczuk’s “The Lost Soul.”
content: Although first published in 2017 in Poland, Olga Tokarczuk’s THE LOST SOUL (Seven Stories, $22.95), an experimental fable illustrated by Joanna Concejo and translated by Antonia Lloyd-Jones, resonates with our current moment. In its carefully executed pages, a man who “slept, ate, worked, drove a car and even played tennis” wakes up in a hotel room forgetting his purpose, location and name. He guesses Andrew or Matthew before checking his passport: It’s John. He consults “a wise old doctor,” who repeats a phrase that appears, unanchored, in the book’s otherwise wordless prologue, next to a drawing of a postage stamp: “If someone could look down on us from above, they’d see that the world is full of people running about in a hurry, sweating and very tired, and their lost souls.”

He acquits himself well on all counts except maybe scripting (he wrote the story with Daniel Weissenberger). Like “Our House” (2018), Burns’s underseen feature debut, “Come True” is superior throwback horror marred mainly by familiarity and, in this case, an ending that feels like a tease.

content: Last March, during the two and a half weeks I spent in quarantine — sick with a mild case of Covid-19 and sequestered with my young daughter — I religiously marked off the days until it would be safe for us to leave the apartment, daydreaming constantly about what it would be like: walking on the sidewalk beneath bare tree branches rattling in the wind, skin striped by cold sunlight, watching my toddler point at the purple door she loved across the street. But once the day of our freedom came, I delayed another day, and then another day after that. At the time, I told myself it was caution — wanting to make doubly, triply sure we were no longer infectious — but I think I was also loath to give up the horizon itself, the end of our sequestering. Some part of me knew I wouldn’t get another ending for a while.
